issue.title: macos, laggy if move mouse on startup (window being created).

labels.name: hacktoberfest
labels.description: Good options for hactoberfest contributions. Not exclusive

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Neovide becomes laggy when I move mouse during the startup.
As Neovide will create a maximized window during startup (after click the app icon in dock), during the window being created and zooming out in the screen, if I move mouse, Neovide becomes laggy (maybe losing frames?) and does not recover even after performing some actions.
But when I deliberately keep the mouse not moved and wait for the window created, zoomed out and completely stable, the problem disappears.
It can be reproduced stably in my environment.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Click the App icon in Dock
2. Immediately move mouse in the window being created and zooming out.
3. After the window created completely, Neovide becomes laggy (maybe losing frames) and never recovers.

**Expected behavior**
Running fluently of course.

**Screenshots**
Not really useful I think. But if you need one, I'll provide.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: macOS Ventura 13.6 (22G120), Intel CPU, macbook pro 13inch.
 - Neovide Version 0.11.2 (cask from homebrew)
 - Neovim Version (from homebrew)
```
NVIM v0.9.2
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3
```
Logs:
There are two files after run with --log. Both are two long, so I make a zip of them.
Dir `good` for the good one
Dir `bad` for the bug one
[log.zip](https://github.com/neovide/neovide/files/12856695/log.zip)

Feel free to ask me for more info if you need! I love Neovide! Thanks so much!

comment.body: Yes, I guess that's what needs to be done if it's implemented here. But if it's implemented in Winit, I think you can hook into this event https://github.com/rust-windowing/winit/blob/53ca5af48ff5cf17ca0fa0012f1860e582fa9402/src/platform_impl/macos/window_delegate.rs#L417-L428

labels.name: hacktoberfest

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

```

Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3
```
Logs:

Dir `good` for the good one
Dir `bad` for the bug one

Feel free to ask me for more info if you need! I love Neovide! Thanks so much!

comment.body:
> @crupest, I checked this a bit more, but forgot to write a comment. The Winit redraw request is actually per window, so which is always bound to a single montitor, so at least that part does not need any re-design of how things work.
> 
> https://docs.rs/winit/latest/winit/event/enum.WindowEvent.html#variant.RedrawRequested

The problem is that the window can move between different screen. If you just have one screen, it is simple. But since the display link is bound to a screen, we have to create a new display link when window moves. The most ideal way is there had an event of window movement between screens. But I guess it could be implemented by just `Moved` and check if the screen changes.

**Describe the bug**

**To Reproduce**

comment.body:
Yes. This issue might be related to screen, OpenGL and compositor.
I'm using a MacBook Pro with Intel cpu and builtin 60Hz screen. But in previous discussion, we found the compositor runs at 120Hz and OpenGL vsync does not work correctly. So it is quite normal if you can't reproduce it.

pull_request.title: Fix option as meta
pull_request.body:
<!-- Please note that we accept pull requests from anyone, but that does not mean it will be merged. -->

## What kind of change does this PR introduce?
- Fix
This re-implements support for the alt_is_meta feature for macOS using winit's `OptionAsMeta` interface, [as requested](https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/2017#issuecomment-1712955629).

It also introduces the ability to map only the left or only the right 'option' key to the virtual key 'meta',  which leaves the other 'option' key free so that it can be used to access the additional two layers of the macOS input source. (E.g. with the u.s. english input source selected, option-c produces "ç" and option-shift-c produces "Ç".) This is done by setting the nvim variable:

```
vim.g.neovide_input_macos_option_key_is_meta
```

Possible values (defined by winit::platform::macos::OptionAsAlt) are:
```
    "Both"
    "OnlyLeft"
    "OnlyRight"
    "None"
```

The preëxisting variable `vim.g.neovide_input_macos_alt_is_meta` can still be used, and if true, it will internally result in the use of OptionAsAlt::Both.

This PR also fixes an issue where, on macOS, format_modifier_string() [would include "S-" for "meta + shift + cmd + y"](https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/2017#issuecomment-1712827024) (producing `<M-S-D-Y>` instead of `<M-D-Y>`)

## Did this PR introduce a breaking change?
if the user changes the nvim variable `vim.g.neovide_input_macos_alt_is_meta` after startup, it will now be ignored. This is not ideal, but from within `WinitWindowWrapper::synchronize_settings()`, there isn't a way to tell whether the legacy variable setting happened before or after a use of the new variable (`vim.g.neovide_input_macos_option_key_is_meta`). The workaround is to use the new variable.

Potentially, this breaking change could be avoided; see the comment in `WinitWindowWrapper::new()`

Fwiw, this is my first attempt at using the Rust programming language (outside of small toy examples from several years ago), so I probably made some mistakes that a beginner would make.

Also note that this PR is based on [fredizzimo:fsundvik/fix-ctrl-shift](https://github.com/neovide/neovide/pull/2018).

repo.name: neovide
repo.description: No Nonsense Neovim Client in Rust

repo.name: neovide
repo.description: No Nonsense Neovim Client in Rust

comment.body: Yes, it looks like you are correct. I just thought that this is some abstraction they should provide, but it does not seems like they do.

issue.title: Support image.nvim / Kitty Graphics Protocol / image rendering in Neovide
issue.body:
Kitty, Konsole, WezTerm (and others) - have been exposing an image rendering API. Image.nvim provides a compelling implementation, rendering images in buffers, allowing for scrolling, images directly in markdown files, lua api, image filters

https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/graphics-protocol/
https://github.com/3rd/image.nvim

Imo this is exactly what Neovide is for. Sensible, non-intrusive extensions to Neovim's power. This is the kind of feature that's only possible when the terminal emulator and the editor are working together. There's already dozens of projects that support the Kitty Graphics Protocol approach, with countless applications - that make Neovim even more awesome

I may be personally convinced to help unless there's someone with  more time/passion available. Though I'd like to know the feasibility given the ongoing changes in the rendering engine

Imo this is exactly what Neovide is for. Sensible, non-intrusive extensions to Neovim's power. This is the kind of feature that's only possible when the terminal emulator and the editor are working together. There's already dozens of projects that support the Kitty Graphics Protocol approach, with countless applications - that make Neovim even more awesome

I may be personally convinced to help unless there's someone with  more time/passion available. Though I'd like to know the feasibility given the ongoing changes in the rendering engine

comment.body: Thank you very much for taking the time to explain all of that, and yeah obviously you're incredibly right. Even if we could support the protocol as-is, it wouldn't do a good job. Anyway, I'm at ease knowing that you're already on top of this - and I'm still very excited about the future that can be created here. Though I understand the challenge, because you're basically describing a simple version of the X Windows network protocol

issue.title: Support image.nvim / Kitty Graphics Protocol / image rendering in Neovide
issue.body:
Kitty, Konsole, WezTerm (and others) - have been exposing an image rendering API. Image.nvim provides a compelling implementation, rendering images in buffers, allowing for scrolling, images directly in markdown files, lua api, image filters

https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/graphics-protocol/
https://github.com/3rd/image.nvim

Imo this is exactly what Neovide is for. Sensible, non-intrusive extensions to Neovim's power. This is the kind of feature that's only possible when the terminal emulator and the editor are working together. There's already dozens of projects that support the Kitty Graphics Protocol approach, with countless applications - that make Neovim even more awesome

I may be personally convinced to help unless there's someone with  more time/passion available. Though I'd like to know the feasibility given the ongoing changes in the rendering engine

comment.body:
> > > Neovide is not using a terminal and based on what I see `image.nvim` is directly writing to a terminal which will do nothing in the setup when neovim and neovide are connected via a socket. I do not say however it is impossible, just without image rendering support by neovim itself it would mean that image.nvim and neovide will both have to be modified — which is not a good thing because `image.nvim` is not the only project that displays images in neovim..
> > 
> > 
> > I'm not sure what you're saying here. The graphics protocol works like terminal input, so you can stream it to whatever terminal emulator supports it, over the network or whatever. Neovide is a terminal emulator. Yes, there are several different attempts, and image.nvim supports two different methods. However Neovide supports 0, which is tremendously behind everyone. Even iTerm has their own version of this - but the Kitty Graphics Protocol is the most likely to win out. WezTerm supports pretty much every method. Neovim itself doesn't need to be modified, plugins can interact with these protocols directly - though I can see a future where they become standardized in core. `image.nvim` would not need to be modified if we support the protocol to handle the terminal input & escape sequences
> 
> None of neovim GUIs are terminal emulators. They receive various rendering commands from neovim using its own messagepack-based RPC protocol which is not the same protocol used by terminal applications to communicate with terminals. They only look like terminal emulators because vim was originally terminal application and RPC was added much later to a preexisting codebase.

Ah okay. I assumed you could still send terminal inputs, and interpret them somehow

issue.title: macos, laggy if move mouse on startup (window being created).

labels.name: hacktoberfest
labels.description: Good options for hactoberfest contributions. Not exclusive

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Neovide becomes laggy when I move mouse during the startup.
As Neovide will create a maximized window during startup (after click the app icon in dock), during the window being created and zooming out in the screen, if I move mouse, Neovide becomes laggy (maybe losing frames?) and does not recover even after performing some actions.
But when I deliberately keep the mouse not moved and wait for the window created, zoomed out and completely stable, the problem disappears.
It can be reproduced stably in my environment.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Click the App icon in Dock
2. Immediately move mouse in the window being created and zooming out.
3. After the window created completely, Neovide becomes laggy (maybe losing frames) and never recovers.

**Expected behavior**
Running fluently of course.

**Screenshots**
Not really useful I think. But if you need one, I'll provide.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: macOS Ventura 13.6 (22G120), Intel CPU, macbook pro 13inch.
 - Neovide Version 0.11.2 (cask from homebrew)
 - Neovim Version (from homebrew)
```
NVIM v0.9.2
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3
```
Logs:
There are two files after run with --log. Both are two long, so I make a zip of them.
Dir `good` for the good one
Dir `bad` for the bug one
[log.zip](https://github.com/neovide/neovide/files/12856695/log.zip)

Feel free to ask me for more info if you need! I love Neovide! Thanks so much!

comment.body: The vsync issues are very random, and this is only one way it can happen, and I don’t think all systems see any symptoms. I suspect having multiple monitors configured also affects the behavior.

comment.body:
OK, 

```
cargo run --profile profiling --features profiling -- --no-fork -- --clean
```

Produces:

[output.tracy.zip](https://github.com/neovide/neovide/files/13168369/output.tracy.zip)

FWIW i cant reproduce the initial issue, is there a specific thing I can try? I read the thread but if anyone knows off hand any specific commands that have been found or actions?

I have tried moving mouse, copying pasting, doing everything. It runs extremely smooth
